fortuitous: having no cause or apparent cause
ingenuous: characterized by an inability to mask your feelings; not devious
sententious: abounding in or given to pompous or aphoristic moralizing
androgynous: having both male and female characteristics
relating to or exhibiting both female and male sex organs but with a predominantly female appearance
autochthonous: of rocks, deposits, etc.; found where they and their constituents were formed
herbaceous: characteristic of a nonwoody herb or plant part
nacreous: having a play of lustrous rainbow colors
opprobrious: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
libidinous: driven by lust; preoccupied with or exhibiting lustful desires
pusillanimous: lacking in courage and manly strength and resolution; contemptibly fearful
uxorious: foolishly fond of or submissive to your wife
anhydrous: without water; especially without water of crystallization
anomalous: deviating from the general or common order or type
diaphanous: so thin as to transmit light
contentious: inclined or showing an inclination to dispute or disagree, even to engage in law suits
involving or likely to cause controversy
duteous: willingly obedient out of a sense of duty and respect
glutinous: having the sticky properties of an adhesive
heterogeneous: consisting of elements that are not of the same kind or nature
judicious: marked by the exercise of good judgment or common sense in practical matters
invidious: containing or implying a slight or showing prejudice
licentious: lacking moral discipline; especially sexually unrestrained
ligneous: consisting of or containing lignin or xylem
litigious: inclined or showing an inclination to dispute or disagree, even to engage in law suits
obsequious: attempting to win favor from influential people by flattery
attentive in an ingratiating or servile manner
platitudinous: dull and tiresome but with pretensions of significance or originality
salacious: suggestive of or tending to moral looseness
sedulous: marked by care and persistent effort
saponaceous: resembling or having the qualities of soap
salubrious: favorable to health of mind or body
unctuous: unpleasantly and excessively suave or ingratiating in manner or speech
factious: dissenting (especially dissenting with the majority opinion)
promiscuous: casual and unrestrained in sexual behavior
not selective of a single class or person
amorphous: having no definite form or distinct shape
without real or apparent crystalline form
lacking the system or structure characteristic of living bodies
(of a group of people or an organization) unorganized or unfocused
unclear because vague or badly organized
autonomous: (of political bodies) not controlled by outside forces
(of persons) free from external control and constraint in e.g. action and judgment
blasphemous: grossly irreverent toward what is held to be sacred
captious: tending to find and call attention to faults
contiguous: having a common boundary or edge; abutting; touching
very close or connected in space or time
connecting without a break; within a common boundary
decorous: characterized by propriety and dignity and good taste in manners and conduct
clamorous: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
euphonious: (of speech or dialect) pleasing in sound; not harsh or strident
impecunious: not having enough money to pay for necessities
felicitous: exhibiting an agreeably appropriate manner or style
inglorious: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
lustrous: made smooth and bright by or as if by rubbing; reflecting a sheen or glow
meticulous: marked by precise accordance with details
marked by extreme care in treatment of details
melodious: containing or constituting or characterized by pleasing melody
having a musical sound; especially a pleasing tune
meretricious: like or relating to a prostitute
precocious: characterized by or characteristic of exceptionally early development or maturity (especially in mental aptitude)
sebaceous: containing an unusual amount of grease or oil
seditious: in opposition to a civil authority or government
tenuous: very thin in gauge or diameter
voracious: devouring or craving food in great quantities
contemporaneous: occurring in the same period of time
lascivious: driven by lust; preoccupied with or exhibiting lustful desires
abstemious: sparing in consumption of especially food and drink
precipitous: done with very great haste and without due deliberation
acrimonious: marked by strong resentment or cynicism
ambidextrous: marked by deliberate deceptiveness especially by pretending one set of feelings and acting under the influence of another
amphibious: relating to or characteristic of animals of the class Amphibia
operating or living on land and in water
homogeneous: all of the same or similar kind or nature
cadaverous: very thin especially from disease or hunger or cold
of or relating to a cadaver or corpse
avaricious: immoderately desirous of acquiring e.g. wealth
conscientious: characterized by extreme care and great effort
guided by or in accordance with conscience or sense of right and wrong
credulous: disposed to believe on little evidence
showing a lack of judgment or experience
coniferous: of or relating to or part of trees or shrubs bearing cones and evergreen leaves
egregious: conspicuously and outrageously bad or reprehensible
deciduous: (of plants and shrubs) shedding foliage at the end of the growing season
(of teeth, antlers, etc.) being shed at the end of a period of growth
devious: indirect in departing from the accepted or proper way; misleading
characterized by insincerity or deceit; evasive
extraneous: not belonging to that in which it is contained; introduced from an outside source
not pertinent to the matter under consideration
fabulous: based on or told of in traditional stories; lacking factual basis or historical validity
fractious: stubbornly resistant to authority or control
unpredictably difficult in operation; likely to be troublesome
impious: lacking piety or reverence for a god
innocuous: lacking intent or capacity to injure
not injurious to physical or mental health
nauseous: causing or able to cause nausea
feeling nausea; feeling about to vomit
nebulous: of or relating to or resembling a nebula
posthumous: occurring or coming into existence after a person's death
penurious: not having enough money to pay for necessities
pernicious: working or spreading in a hidden and usually injurious way
prodigious: far beyond what is usual in magnitude or degree
so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
sinuous: curved or curving in and out
gracefully thin and bending and moving with ease
rigorous: rigidly accurate; allowing no deviation from a standard
demanding strict attention to rules and procedures
synchronous: occurring or existing at the same time or having the same period or phase

crustaceous: of or belonging to the class Crustacea
being or having or resembling a hard crust or shell
dissentious: dissenting (especially dissenting with the majority opinion)
fallacious: containing or based on a fallacy
based on an incorrect or misleading notion or information
ignominious: (used of conduct or character) deserving or bringing disgrace or shame
insidious: working or spreading in a hidden and usually injurious way
mucous: of or secreting or covered with or resembling mucus
officious: intrusive in a meddling or offensive manner
surreptitious: conducted with or marked by hidden aims or methods
marked by quiet and caution and secrecy; taking pains to avoid being observed
amorous: expressive of or exciting sexual love or romance
anthropomorphous: suggesting human characteristics for animals or inanimate things
usurious: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation
aqueous: produced by the action of water
similar to or containing or dissolved in water
bibulous: given to or marked by the consumption of alcohol
continuous: continuing in time or space without interruption
of a function or curve; extending without break or irregularity
extemporaneous: with little or no preparation or forethought
pendulous: having branches or flower heads that bend downward
odorous: having odor or a characteristic odor
pugnacious: ready and able to resort to force or violence
tough and callous by virtue of experience
punctilious: marked by precise accordance with details
semiconscious: partially conscious; not completely aware of sensations
spurious: false or fake; not what it appears to be
ostensibly valid, but not actually valid
venous: of or contained in or performing the function of the veins
uproarious: marked by or causing boisterous merriment or convulsive laughter
analogous: similar or equivalent in some respects though otherwise dissimilar
corresponding in function but not in evolutionary origin
impervious: not admitting of passage or capable of being affected
incongruous: lacking in harmony or compatibility or appropriateness
assiduous: marked by care and persistent effort
porous: full of pores or vessels or holes
arduous: taxing to the utmost; testing powers of endurance
characterized by effort to the point of exhaustion; especially physical effort
difficult to accomplish; demanding considerable mental effort and skill
bilious: suffering from or suggesting a liver disorder or gastric distress
irritable as if suffering from indigestion
tortuous: highly complex or intricate and occasionally devious
marked by repeated turns and bends
copious: large in number or quantity (especially of discourse)
desirous: having or expressing desire for something
gregarious: instinctively or temperamentally seeking and enjoying the company of others
(of animals) tending to form a group with others of the same species
(of plants) growing in groups that are close together
fastidious: having complicated nutritional requirements; especially growing only in special artificial cultures
giving careful attention to detail; hard to please; excessively concerned with cleanliness
igneous: produced under conditions involving intense heat
produced by the action of fire or intense heat
ludicrous: broadly or extravagantly humorous; resembling farce
so unreasonable as to invite derision
iniquitous: characterized by iniquity; wicked because it is believed to be a sin
libelous: (used of statements) harmful and often untrue; tending to discredit or malign
intravenous: within or by means of a vein
malicious: having the nature of or resulting from malice
ostentatious: intended to attract notice and impress others
pious: having or showing or expressing reverence for a deity
pretentious: intended to attract notice and impress others
making claim to or creating an appearance of (often undeserved) importance or distinction
studious: characterized by diligent study and fondness for reading
scrupulous: characterized by extreme care and great effort
having scruples; arising from a sense of right and wrong; principled
ridiculous: broadly or extravagantly humorous; resembling farce
so unreasonable as to invite derision
stupendous: so great in size or force or extent as to elicit awe
subconscious: psychic activity just below the level of awareness
just below the level of consciousness
timorous: timid by nature or revealing timidity
synonymous: (of words) meaning the same or nearly the same
treacherous: tending to betray; especially having a treacherous character as attributed to the Carthaginians by the Romans
zealous: marked by active interest and enthusiasm
vociferous: conspicuously and offensively loud; given to vehement outcry
simultaneous: occurring or operating at the same time
ambiguous: open to two or more interpretations; or of uncertain nature or significance; or (often) intended to mislead
having more than one possible meaning
having no intrinsic or objective meaning; not organized in conventional patterns
cantankerous: stubbornly obstructive and unwilling to cooperate
having a difficult and contrary disposition
anonymous: having no known name or identity or known source
not known or lacking marked individuality
contagious: (of disease) capable of being transmitted by infection
easily diffused or spread as from one person to another
courteous: characterized by courtesy and gracious good manners
carnivorous: (used of plants as well as animals) feeding on animals
relating to or characteristic of carnivores
felonious: involving or being or having the nature of a crime
fictitious: formed or conceived by the imagination
grievous: of great gravity or crucial import; requiring serious thought
causing or marked by grief or anguish
causing fear or anxiety by threatening great harm
harmonious: exhibiting equivalence or correspondence among constituents of an entity or between different entities
impetuous: characterized by undue haste and lack of thought or deliberation
raucous: disturbing the public peace; loud and rough
tremulous: (of the voice) quivering as from weakness or fear
sacrilegious: grossly irreverent toward what is held to be sacred
advantageous: appropriate for achieving a particular end; implies a lack of concern for fairness
dexterous: skillful in physical movements; especially of the hands
unanimous: acting together as a single undiversified whole
strenuous: taxing to the utmost; testing powers of endurance
characterized by or performed with much energy or force

vicious: marked by deep ill will; deliberately harmful
(of persons or their actions) able or disposed to inflict pain or suffering

ambitious: requiring full use of your abilities or resources
having a strong desire for success or achievement
callous: having calluses; having skin made tough and thick through wear
make insensitive or callous; deaden feelings or morals
audacious: disposed to venture or take risks
boisterous: full of rough and exuberant animal spirits
noisy and lacking in restraint or discipline
conscious: (followed by `of') showing realization or recognition of something

ceremonious: rigidly formal or bound by convention
characterized by pomp and ceremony and stately display
enormous: extraordinarily large in size or extent or amount or power or degree

conspicuous: without any attempt at concealment; completely obvious
obvious to the eye or mind

envious: showing extreme cupidity; painfully desirous of another's advantages
hideous: so extremely ugly as to be terrifying
grossly offensive to decency or morality; causing horror
hilarious: marked by or causing boisterous merriment or convulsive laughter
industrious: characterized by hard work and perseverance
working hard to promote an enterprise
miscellaneous: consisting of a haphazard assortment of different kinds
infectious: caused by infection or capable of causing infection

obvious: easily perceived by the senses or grasped by the mind
ponderous: slow and laborious because of weight
having great mass and weight and unwieldiness
prosperous: in fortunate circumstances financially; moderately rich
presaging or likely to bring good luck or a good outcome
religious: concerned with sacred matters or religion or the church
a member of a religious order who is bound by vows of poverty and chastity and obedience
having or showing belief in and reverence for a deity

spacious: (of buildings and rooms) having ample space
very large in expanse or scope
suspicious: openly distrustful and unwilling to confide
unconscious: that part of the mind wherein psychic activity takes place of which the person is unaware
not conscious; lacking awareness and the capacity for sensory perception as if asleep or dead
curious: beyond or deviating from the usual or expected
eager to investigate and learn or learn more (sometimes about others' concerns)
ferocious: marked by extreme and violent energy
virtuous: in a state of sexual virginity
furious: marked by extreme and violent energy
(of the elements) as if showing violent anger
generous: more than is usual or necessary
not petty in character and mind
willing to give and share unstintingly
gracious: characterized by kindness and warm courtesy especially of a king to his subjects
characterized by charm, good taste, and generosity of spirit
luscious: extremely pleasing to the sense of taste

suspicious or unduly suspicious or fearful of being displaced by a rival
luxurious: displaying luxury and furnishing gratification to the senses
ostentatiously rich and superior in quality
marvelous: too improbable to admit of belief
being or having the character of a miracle
extraordinarily good or great; used especially as intensifiers

being or having the character of a miracle
monotonous: tediously repetitious or lacking in variety
sounded or spoken in a tone unvarying in pitch
nervous: of or relating to the nervous system
causing or fraught with or showing anxiety
ominous: threatening or foreshadowing evil or tragic developments
numerous: amounting to a large indefinite number
serious: causing fear or anxiety by threatening great harm
concerned with work or important matters rather than play or trivialities

spontaneous: happening or arising without apparent external cause

various: of many different kinds purposefully arranged but lacking any uniformity

venomous: marked by deep ill will; deliberately harmful
extremely poisonous or injurious; producing venom

mountainous: like a mountain in size and impressiveness
tremendous: extreme in degree or extent or amount or impact

outrageous: greatly exceeding bounds of reason or moderation
grossly offensive to decency or morality; causing horror
deceitful: marked by deliberate deceptiveness especially by pretending one set of feelings and acting under the influence of another
frightful: extreme in degree or extent or amount or impact
artful: not straightforward or candid; giving a false appearance of frankness

serving as or indicating the existence of a purpose or goal

inspiring awe or admiration or wonder
extreme in degree or extent or amount or impact

affected by or full of grief or woe
beautiful: delighting the senses or exciting intellectual or emotional admiration
handful: the quantity that can be held in the hand

characterized by or full of force or strength (often but not necessarily physical)
unsuccessful: failing to accomplish an intended result
not successful; having failed or having an unfavorable outcome
cheerful: being full of or promoting cheer; having or showing good spirits
colorful: having color or a certain color; sometimes used in combination

successful: having succeeded or being marked by a favorable outcome

careful: unhurried and with care and dignity
mindful of the future in spending money
exercising caution or showing care or attention
fearful: timid by nature or revealing timidity
lacking courage; ignobly timid and faint-hearted
causing fear or dread or terror
forgetful: (of memory) deficient in retentiveness or range

powerful: strong enough to knock down or overwhelm
(Southern regional intensive) very; to a great degree

having great power or force or potency or effect
wonderful: extraordinarily good or great; used especially as intensifiers

fearless: oblivious of dangers or perils or calmly resolute in facing them
restless: lacking or not affording physical or mental rest
